Problem:
Consider a fluid mechanic system where the velocity field \\( \\vec{v}(x, t) \\) is governed by the Navier-Stokes equation \\( \\partial_t \\vec{v} + (\\vec{v} \\cdot \\nabla)\\vec{v} = -\\frac{1}{\\rho} \\nabla p + \\nu \\nabla^2 \\vec{v} \\). We introduce a scalar field temperature \\( T(x,t) \\) affected by both convection and diffusion, described by the advection-diffusion equation \\( \\partial_t T + \\vec{v} \\cdot \\nabla T = \\kappa \\nabla^2 T \\), where \\( \\kappa \\) is the diffusion coefficient.

If the velocity field \\( \\vec{v}(x, t) \\) undergoes a sudden change at t = 0 due to an external force, will the temperature distribution \\( T(x, T) \\) at a later time T still obey the original advection-diffusion equation dynamics without considering this change in velocity?
Explanation: The change in the velocity field directly affects the convective term \\( \\vec{v} \\cdot \\nabla T \\) in the advection-diffusion equation. This alteration changes the way temperature is transported and diffused across the medium, resulting in different temperature distributions.
